The actual resolution may be 1280Ă720p, but quality is poorer than a DVD. Copoid VHS, I would say. I don't understand why compromise compressions less than 1GB satisfy people. Memory is surely not a problem in 2010.
thnx man....

@FDNG

Technology changes, son.  H.264 has a dramatically better compression algorithm than just about anything else right now, so you can get much higher quality video in a lower file size.  A comparable Xvid rip would be at least twice as large.  Why waste your time downloading a 2 GB rip of inferior quality when you could be done and watching the movie in half the time?
Also, thanks RiddlerA, this is one of my all time faves!

Agreed with FDNG. The quality here is awful. High resolution is meaningless if there's a lot of pixelation because the bitrate is too low. Downloaded it and this is definitely much worse quality than my Excalibur DVD. But I should have known better beforehand. A good 720p rip of a feature-length movie is about 4.4GB. There's no way an 800GB file will have any decent detail. In fact, when I encode my own DVDs using x264, an extra-long movie like this comes out best around 900MB-1GB, and that's at 480p, which has less than 40% of the pixels of a 720p rip.

If you love this movie like I do, do yourself a favor and avoid this horribly overcompressed rip. "fuckfrank" doesn't know what he's talking about. He thinks H.264 is some kind of magical codec that will allow 15GB HD DVD movies to be compressed down to 800MB with minimal loss of quality. Blu-ray and HD DVD already use H.264! You're not going to compress it to 1/20th of its size.

honunet,

Stupid? The stupid thing is that you think this rip is good. In fact, download one of the 4GB or larger 720p rips of Excalibur and you will see excellent image quality for "30 year old media." It makes no sense to download a poor quality 720p rip just to be able to watch it quickly. If speed is of the essence, grab a 1GB 480p DVD rip which will look better because it's not overcompressed. Otherwise, if quality is important, and it must be if you want a 720p video, spring $50 for a 1.5TB drive if you don't have enough disk space and spend the extra day downloading the good stuff. Good things come to those who wait.
